words.def: A specific category of three-lane road, consisting of two lanes in one direction and one lane in the other, alternating every few kilometres, and separated usually with a steel cable barrier.
words.name: 2+1 road

words.def: A specific type of dual carriageway being built in Ireland, Sweden, and Finland, consisting of two lanes in each direction separated by a steel cable barrier.
words.name: 2+2 road

words.def: See three-way junction
words.name: 3-way junction or 3-way intersection

words.def: A transportation and traffic information telephone hotline in some regions of the United States and Canada that was initially designated for road weather information.
See frontage road
words.name: Access road

words.def: A highway that splits off the mainline and reconnects some distance later.
words.name: Alternate route or optional route

words.def: A junction at which two or more roads cross at the same level or grade.
words.name: At-grade intersection

words.def: A measure of total volume of vehicle traffic on a segment of road for a year divided by 365 days to produce an average.
words.name: Annual average daily traffic (AADT)

words.def: A high-capacity urban road designed to deliver traffic at the highest possible level of service.
words.name: Arterial road or arterial thoroughfare

words.def: A highway that supplements a major or mainline highway.
words.name: Auxiliary route

words.def: A method of collecting tolls on highways using toll barriers at regularly spaced intervals on the toll road's mainline, usually charging a flat rate at each barrier.
words.name: Barrier toll system or open toll system

words.def: See ring road
words.name: Beltway

words.def: A road traffic control measure designed to prevent congestion and gridlock at junctions. The surface of the junction is typically marked with a criss-cross grid of diagonal painted lines (or only two lines crossing each other in the box), and vehicles may not enter the area so marked unless their exit from the junction is clear (or, if turning, to await a gap in the oncoming traffic flow).
words.name: Box junction

words.def: A lane restricted to buses, and sometimes certain other vehicles such as taxis.
words.name: Bus lane

words.def: An auxiliary route that passes through the central business district of a city.
words.name: Business route or city route

words.def: See stack interchange
words.name: Butterfly junction

words.def: An auxiliary route that relieves congestion along the mainline by routing traffic around a city or congested area. Can also be used to refer to a segment of road built to reroute the mainline away from a city or congested area.
words.name: Bypass

words.def: The gradient of the road surface at 90° to the direction of travel; the difference in height between the edge and the crown of the road.
words.name: Cant or camber

words.def: A width of road on which a vehicle is not restricted by any physical barriers or separation to move laterally. A roadway can comprise one or more carriageways; single carriageways may contain both directions of traffic for the roadway, while multiple carriageways can separate traffic by direction or type.
words.name: Carriageway

words.def: A retroreflective safety device used in road marking and the first of a range of raised pavement markers.
words.name: Cat's eye

words.def: See median strip
words.name: Central reservation

words.def: See ring road
words.name: Circumferential highway

words.def: See business route
words.name: City route

words.def: See ticket system
words.name: Closed toll collection system

words.def: A two-level interchange in which turns are handled by eight total ramp or slip roads, four of which form loops that give the interchange the shape of a cloverleaf from the air. Each ramp allows traffic from one direction of a roadway to access only one direction of the crossroad: e.g. from northbound to eastbound while a separate ramp connects from northbound to westbound. Traffic is fully grade separated; it does not need to stop to make any of the connections between the two roadways.
words.name: Cloverleaf interchange or cloverleaf junction

words.def: See hurricane evacuation route
words.name: Coastal evacuation route

words.def: See local-express lanes
words.name: Collector–distributor lanes

words.def: An instance of one physical road bearing two or more different highway, motorway, or other route numbers.
words.name: Concurrency

words.def: An auxiliary route that provides a shortcut between two routes or a connection between two routes that otherwise do no connect.
words.name: Connector or cutoff

words.def: A highway defined in the constitution of the place in which it is located. Only found in Minnesota.
words.name: Constitutional route

words.def: An intersection where vehicles attempting to turn across the opposing direction of traffic (left in right-hand drive jurisdictions; right in left-hand drive jurisdictions) cross before they enter the intersection. No left turn signal in the intersection is then necessary.
words.name: Continuous-flow intersection, CFI, crossover displaced left-turn, XDL, or DLT

words.def: See seagull intersection
words.name: Continuous green T-intersection

words.def: The reversal of direction of traffic in a lane, to facilitate emergency evacuations, roadworks, or events.
words.name: Contraflow lane reversal

words.def: A type of highway which has been designed for high-speed vehicular traffic, with all traffic flow and ingress/egress regulated.
words.name: Controlled-access highway, motorway, or freeway

words.def: See rumble strips
words.name: The corduroy

words.def: A road in the United States and in the Canadian province of Ontario that is designated and/or maintained by the county highway department.
words.name: County highway, county road, or county route

words.def: See one-way pair
words.name: Couplet

words.def: See pedestrian crossing
words.name: Crosswalk

words.def: A street with only one inlet/outlet.
words.name: Cul-de-sac, dead end, closed, no through road, no exit, court, or no outlet

words.def: See cul-de-sac
words.name: Dead end

words.def: A former highway which was removed from the highway system is said to be decommissioned. The term also applies to a designation which was removed from a highway system, such as when the U.S. Route 66 was removed from the United States Numbered Highway System in 1985. The physical roadbed typically remains usable, and it may then receive a different designation as another classification of road.[1][2]
words.name: Decommissioned highway

words.def: An interchange between a freeway and a minor road where the off-ramp diverges only slightly from the freeway and runs directly across the minor road at an at-grade intersection, becoming an on-ramp that returns to the freeway in similar fashion.
words.name: Diamond interchange

words.def: See stack interchange
words.name: Directional interchange

words.def: A type of diamond interchange in which the two directions of traffic on the non-freeway road cross to the opposite side on both sides of the bridge at the freeway.
words.name: Diverging diamond interchange, DDI, double crossover diamond interchange, or DCD

words.def: See continuous-flow intersection
words.name: DLT

words.def: A class of highway with two carriageways for traffic traveling in opposite directions separated by a median strip or central reservation.
words.name: Dual carriageway or divided highway

words.def: Regulations that govern the activities of commercial truck drivers, most notably limiting the number of hours a person may drive during the day or week.
words.name: Drivers' working hours

words.def: See variable-message sign
words.name: Dynamic message sign

words.def: A system of toll collection where a driver attaches a transponder to his or her vehicle or where a camera recognizes the vehicle registration plates. Tolls are charged automatically to the driver, either by prepaid account or by regular billing, when the vehicle passes through a toll booth or gantry.
words.name: Electronic toll collection

words.def: See runaway truck ramp
words.name: Escape lane or emergency escape ramp

words.def: See hurricane evacuation route
words.name: Evacuation route

words.def: A number assigned to a road junction, usually an exit from a freeway.
words.name: Exit number

words.def: See limited-access road
words.name: Expressway

words.def: A highway that connects rural or agricultural areas to market towns.
words.name: Farm-to-market road, ranch-to-market road, farm road, or ranch road

words.def: See controlled-access highway
words.name: Freeway

words.def: A local road running parallel to a higher-speed, limited-access road.
words.name: Frontage road, access road, service road, or parallel road

words.def: A flood plain crossing built at or close to the natural ground level,[3] designed to be submerged under water, but withstand such conditions—typically used when flood frequency or time span is minimal, traffic volumes are low, and the cost of a bridge is uneconomic.[4]
words.name: Floodway

words.def: See sidewalk
words.name: Footpath or footway

words.def: See traffic island
words.name: Ghost island

words.def: A triangular piece of land found where roads merge or split.
words.name: Gore, gore point, gore zone, or merge nose

words.def: The degree by which a road rises or declines, affected by fills and cuts designed and built to reduce the steepness of a road.
words.name: Grade, slope, incline, gradient, pitch or rise

words.def: The method of aligning a junction of two or more road axes at different heights (grades) so that they will not disrupt the traffic flow on other transit routes when they cross each other.
words.name: Grade separation

words.def: See rumble strips
words.name: Growlers

words.def: A system designed to keep people or vehicles from (in most cases unintentionally) straying into dangerous or off-limits areas.
words.name: Guard rail, guardrail, guide rail, or railing

words.def: A bend in a road with a very acute inner angle that resembles a hairpin/bobby pin, making it necessary for an oncoming vehicle to turn almost 180° to continue on the road.
words.name: Hairpin turn, hairpin bend, hairpin corner, or hairpin curve

words.def: The business of transporting goods by road or rail.
words.name: Haulage

words.def: A lane reserved for vehicles carrying two or more passengers or other exempted vehicles.
words.name: High-occupancy vehicle lane or HOV lane

words.def: An HOV lane that charges a toll for vehicles that do not meet HOV regulations.
words.name: High-occupancy toll lane or HOT lane

words.def: See seagull intersection
words.name: High-T intersection

words.def: Any public road or other public way on land. It is used for major roads, but also includes other public roads and public tracks.
words.name: Highway

words.def: A graphical representation of a route number, which serves as navigational aid
words.name: Highway shield or route marker

words.def: See scenic route
words.name: Holiday route

words.def: A right turn made from the left lane (countries that drive on the left), or a left turn made from the right lane (countries that drive on the right).
words.name: Hook turn

words.def: A highway in the United States that is a specified route for hurricane evacuation.
words.name: Hurricane evacuation route, coastal evacuation route, or evacuation route

words.def: See grade
words.name: Incline

words.def: A road junction that typically uses grade separation, and one or more ramps, to permit traffic on at least one highway to pass through the junction without directly crossing any other traffic stream.
words.name: Interchange

words.def: An at-grade road junction of two or more roads either meeting or crossing.
words.name: Intersection

words.def: A modular concrete or plastic barrier employed to separate lanes of traffic.
words.name: Jersey barrier, Jersey wall, K-rail, or Ontario tall wall

words.def: See superstreet
words.name: J-turn

words.def: A type of ramp or slip road where instead of a standard left turn being made from the left lane, left-turning traffic uses a ramp on the right side of the road (in countries that drive on the right).
words.name: Jughandle or Jersey left

words.def: A location where multiple roads intersect, allowing vehicular traffic to change from one road to another.
words.name: Junction

words.def: See Jersey barrier
words.name: K-rail

words.def: See three-point turn
words.name: K-turn

words.def: See road train
words.name: Land train

words.def: Part of a carriageway or roadway that is designated for use by a single line of vehicles, to control and guide drivers and reduce traffic conflicts.[5]
words.name: Lane

words.def: A highway defined by laws passed in a legislature. The numbering of such highways may or may not correspond to the numbers familiar to the posted route number.
words.name: Legislative route

words.def: See right-in/right-out
words.name: Left-in/left-out (LILO)

words.def: A measurement used to describe the quality of traffic on a highway. Levels range from free flowing traffic to constant traffic jams.
words.name: Level of service

words.def: A highway or arterial road for high-speed traffic which has many or most characteristics of a controlled-access highway, including limited or no access to adjacent property, some degree of separation of opposing traffic flow, use of grade separated interchanges to some extent, prohibition of some modes of transport such as bicycles or horses and very few or no intersecting cross-streets. The definitions and degrees of isolation from local traffic allowed varies between countries and regions.[6]
words.name: Limited-access road or expressway

words.def: An arrangement of roadways within a major highway where long distance traffic can use lanes with fewer interchanges compared to local traffic which use 'local' or 'collector' lanes that have access to all interchanges.
words.name: Local-express lanes or collector–distributor lanes

words.def: See Texas U-turn
words.name: Loop Around

words.def: See truck
words.name: Lorry

words.def: See truck driver
words.name: Lorry driver

words.def: A manual published by the Federal Highway Administration in the United States, or similar manuals published by state departments of transportation, that specifies the standards for traffic signs, highway markings, and traffic signals (collectively "traffic control devices"). The manual includes specifications on typefaces, colors, and shapes of signs, as well as placement of these traffic control devices.
words.name: Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices

words.def: See variable-message sign
words.name: Matrix sign

words.def: The reserved area that separates opposing lanes of traffic on divided roadways. The reserved area may simply be paved or grass, but can be adapted to other functions, such as decorative landscaping, trees, a median barrier, or railway or streetcar lines.
words.name: Median strip or central reservation

words.def: The process of reducing the number of lanes available to traffic, commonly from two lanes to one.
words.name: Merge

words.def: See gore
words.name: Merge nose

words.def: An at-grade intersection design which replaces each left turn with a right turn followed by a U-turn, or a U-turn followed by a right turn
words.name: Michigan left

words.def: One of a series of numbered markers placed along a road or boundary at intervals of one mile or occasionally, parts of a mile.
words.name: Milestone, mile markers, mileposts or mile post

words.def: See controlled-access highway
words.name: Motorway

words.def: A road numbered consistently throughout a country. Maintenance of the road may be performed at the national level or it may be devolved to states or provinces or to lower levels of administration. The Interstate Highway System, Trans-Canada Highway, and German autobahns are examples of national highways.
words.name: National highway

words.def: See cul-de-sac
words.name: No through road, no exit, or no outlet

words.def: A pair of parallel, usually one-way streets that carry opposite directions of traffic.
words.name: One-way pair, one-way couple, or couplet

words.def: See Jersey barrier
words.name: Ontario tall wall

words.def: A form of electronic toll collection where tolls are collected at highway speeds without the need for tollbooths.
words.name: Open road tolling

words.def: See barrier toll system
words.name: Open toll system

words.def: See alternate route
words.name: Optional route

words.def: See ring road
words.name: Orbital

words.def: See traffic island
words.name: Painted island

words.def: See frontage road
words.name: Parallel road

words.def: A broad, landscaped highway thoroughfare, particularly a roadway in a park or connecting to a park from which trucks and other heavy vehicles are excluded.[7]
words.name: Parkway

words.def: An interchange that has loop ramps, as in a cloverleaf, but does not have the full set of eight ramps. These use between four and seven ramps and are not full grade-separated; traffic making certain movements between the intersecting roadways must stop.
words.name: Partial cloverleaf interchange, or parclo

words.def: For the material, see road surface. For the path, see sidewalk.
words.name: Pavement

words.def: A designated place for pedestrians to cross a road.
words.name: Pedestrian crossing or crosswalk

words.def: See grade
words.name: Pitch

words.def:
For the type of easement, see right-of-way
The traffic principle that establishes who has the right to go first when the intended courses of vehicles or pedestrians intersect.
words.name: Priority or right of way

words.def: See state highway
words.name: Provincial highway, provincial road, or provincial route

words.def: An intersection between two roads with an additional "quadrant roadway" between two legs of the intersecting roads. Left turns (in right-hand traffic countries) or right turns (in left-hand traffic countries) are made via the quadrant roadway rather than at the main intersection.
words.name: Quadrant roadway intersection or quadrant intersection

words.def: See guard rail
words.name: Railing

words.def: A road surface marker used on roads, usually made with plastic, ceramic, thermoplastic paint or occasionally metal, and come in a variety of shapes and colors.
words.name: Raised pavement marker or raised reflective marker

words.def: See slip road
words.name: Ramp

words.def: See farm-to-market road
words.name: Ranch-to-market road or ranch road

words.def: A public facility, located next to a large thoroughfare such as a highway, expressway, or freeway at which drivers and passengers can rest, eat, or refuel without exiting on to secondary roads.
words.name: Rest area, travel plaza, rest stop, or service area

words.def: See superstreet
words.name: Restricted crossing U-turn (RCUT) or Reduced Conflict Intersection

words.def: A lane in which traffic may travel in either direction, depending on certain conditions. Typically, it is meant to improve traffic flow during rush hours, by having overhead traffic lights and lighted street signs notify drivers which lanes are open or closed to driving or turning.
words.name: Reversible lane or tidal flow

words.def: A type of three-way road intersection where turning movements of vehicles are restricted. A RIRO permits only right turns and a LILO permits only left turns. RIRO is typical when vehicles drive on the right, and LILO is usual where vehicles drive on the left.
words.name: Right-in/right-out (RIRO) or left-in/left-out (LILO)

words.def:
For the traffic principle, see priority
A type of easement granted or reserved over the land for transportation purposes, this can be for a highway, public footpath, rail transport, canal, as well as electrical transmission lines, oil and gas pipelines.[8]
words.name: Right-of-way

words.def: A highway or series of highways that encircle a city or town.
words.name: Ring road, beltway, circumferential highway, or orbital

words.def: See grade
words.name: Rise

words.def: See traffic sign
words.name: Road sign

words.def: Durable surface material laid down on an area intended to sustain vehicular or foot traffic.
words.name: Road surface or pavement

words.def: Mechanical (cat's-eye reflectors), non-mechanical (paint), or temporary devices used on a road surface that convey information to motorists, most commonly to delineate traffic lanes or to promote road safety.
words.name: Road surface marking

words.def: A method of trucking where a tractor pulls two or more trailers.
words.name: Road train or land train

words.def: A type of circular intersection or junction in which road traffic flows almost continuously in one direction around a central island.[9]
words.name: Roundabout, rotary, or traffic circle

words.def: See highway shield
words.name: Route marker

words.def: A combination of letters and/or numbers that serve to identify a particular road. Route numbers may be assigned randomly or as part of a regional numbering scheme.
words.name: Route number, road number, or route identifier

words.def: A road surface mark used to alert inattentive drivers of potential danger, by causing a tactile vibration and audible rumbling transmitted through the wheels into the vehicle interior.
words.name: Rumble strips, sleeper lines, rumple strips, audible lines, the corduroy, or growlers

words.def: An emergency lane with a sand or gravel-filled bed large enough to accommodate and safely stop large trucks, usually adjacent to a road with a steep down-hill grade.
words.name: Runaway truck ramp, runaway truck lane, escape lane, emergency escape ramp or truck arrester bed

words.def: A specially designated road that travels through an area of natural beauty or cultural interest, or along a historic route.
words.name: Scenic route, tourist road, tourist route, tourist drive, holiday route, theme route, or scenic byway

words.def: A type of three-way road intersection, usually used on high traffic volume roads and dual carriageways. In this type of intersection, one direction of traffic travels straight through without stopping while those wishing to turn onto the side road at the intersection simply bear into a separate lane, which forms one 'wing' of the seagull. Here, they meet the opposite carriageway and the side road. Traffic wishing to turn out of the side road, simply cross the intersecting carriageway and drive up the other 'wing' of the seagull, and merge onto the other carriageway.
words.name: Seagull intersection, continuous green T-intersection, turbo-T, or High-T intersection

words.def: A road on which the surface has been permanently sealed by the use of a pavement treatment, such as bitumen.
words.name: Sealed road

words.def: See rest area
words.name: Service area

words.def: See frontage road
words.name: Service road

words.def: A path along the side of a road.
words.name: Sidewalk, footpath, footway, or pavement

words.def: A reserved lane by the verge of a road or motorway.
words.name: Shoulder

words.def: A road with one, two, or more lanes arranged within a roadway or carriageway with no physical separation of opposing flows of traffic.
words.name: Single carriageway or undivided highway

words.def: A variant of the diamond interchange most often used in urban areas where conservation of space is necessitated.
words.name: Single point urban interchange or SPUI

words.def: See rumble strips
words.name: Sleeper lines

words.def: A connector road between the intersecting roads of an interchange.
words.name: Slip road or ramp

words.def: See grade
words.name: Slope

words.def: A nickname sometimes given to a complicated or massively intertwined road traffic interchange that resembles a plate of spaghetti. The term was originally used to refer to the Gravelly Hill Interchange on the M6 in Birmingham.[10]
words.name: Spaghetti Junction

words.def: A prefixed and/or suffixed numbered road in the United States that forms a loop or spur of a more dominant route of the same route number and system.
words.name: Special route

words.def: A family of traffic calming devices that use vertical deflection to slow motor-vehicle traffic in order to improve safety conditions.
words.name: Speed bump, speed hump, speed ramp, speed cushion, or speed table

words.def: The maximum (or minimum in some cases) speed at which road vehicles may travel legally on particular stretches of road.
words.name: Speed limit

words.def: An highway that branches off of the mainline and goes to an area that is not served by the mainline highway.
words.name: Spur route

words.def: A free-flowing, grade-separated junction between two roads, where movements are handled by semi-directional flyovers or under ramps. Vehicles first exit the main carriageway, then complete the turn via a ramp that crosses both highways, eventually merging with the traffic from the opposite side of the interchange.
words.name: Stack interchange, butterfly junction, or directional interchange

words.def: A road numbered or maintained by a state or province.
words.name: State highway, state road, state route, provincial highway, provincial road, or provincial route

words.def: A diagram that describes a road and its features along a straight line.
words.name: Straight-line diagram or strip map

words.def: See unused highway
words.name: Stub ramp, stub street, stub-out, stub, or ski jump

words.def: An at-grade intersection where traffic on the minor road cannot go straight across. Traffic on the minor road wishing to turn left or continue straight must turn right onto the major road, then, a short distance away, use a U-turn (or crossover) lane in the median before either going straight or making a right turn when they intersect the other half of the minor road.
words.name: Superstreet, restricted crossing U-turn (RCUT), J-turn, or Reduced Conflict Intersection

words.def: A two-lane surface road built to highway standards, typically including partial control of access, occasional passing lanes and hard shoulders.
words.name: Super two, super two-lane highway, or wide two lane

words.def: A lane allowing cars traveling on one side of a one-way frontage road to U-turn onto the opposite frontage road (typically crossing over or under a freeway or expressway).
words.name: Texas U-turn, Texas turnaround, or Loop Around

words.def: A method of turning a vehicle around (making a 180° turn) in close quarters, such as in the middle of a road at a point other than an intersection.
words.name: Three-point turn or K-turn

words.def: a type of road intersection with three arms. A Y junction generally has 3 arms of equal size. A T junction also has 3 arms, but one of the arms is generally a minor road connecting to larger road.
words.name: Three-way junction, 3-way junction, 3-way intersection, Y junction, Y intersection, T junction, or T intersection

words.def: A toll road where motorists pay a toll rate based on the distance traveled from their origin to their destination exit. Motorists take a ticket when entering the road and pay the toll and surrender the ticket upon exiting.
words.name: Ticket system or closed toll collection system

words.def: A road for which a fee (or toll) is assessed for passage.
words.name: Toll road, turnpike, or tollway

words.def: See scenic route
words.name: Tourist road, tourist route, tourist drive, or theme route

words.def: Pedestrians, ridden or herded animals, vehicles, streetcars, buses and other conveyances, either singly or together, that use roads for purposes of travel.
words.name: Traffic

words.def: See roundabout
words.name: Traffic circle

words.def: A solid or painted object in a road that channelises traffic.
words.name: Traffic island, painted island, or ghost island

words.def: Signaling devices positioned at road intersections, pedestrian crossings and other locations to control competing flows of traffic.
words.name: Traffic light

words.def: A method of conveying information to people who are using a road. Depending on location, the main color of the sign can tell the motorist what type of information is presented on the sign.
words.name: Traffic sign or road sign

words.def: See rest area
words.name: Travel plaza

words.def: A vehicle designed to carry cargo.
words.name: Truck or lorry

words.def: See runaway truck ramp
words.name: Truck arrester bed

words.def: A person who earns a living by driving a truck
words.name: Truck driver, trucker or truckie, lorry driver, or driver

words.def: A bypass designed for heavy truck traffic.
words.name: Truck route

words.def: A type of junction that allows traffic traveling in one direction on a road to efficiently make a U-turn typically without backing up or making dangerous maneuvers in the middle of the traffic stream.
words.name: Turnaround

words.def: When a motorist must exit a highway to continue traveling on the same numbered route.
words.name: Turn off to stay on (TOTSO)

words.def: See seagull intersection
words.name: Turbo-T

words.def: An expressway with only one lane in each direction, and usually no median barrier.
words.name: Two-lane expressway

words.def: A single carriageway with one lane for each direction.
words.name: Two-lane road

words.def: See single carriageway
words.name: Undivided highway

words.def: A highway or highway ramp that was partially or fully constructed, but was unused or later closed.
words.name: Unused highway, ski jump, stub ramp, stub street, stub-out, or stub

words.def: A 180° rotation to reverse the direction of travel so called because the maneuver looks like the letter U.
words.name: U-turn

words.def: A traffic sign that can display important messages about special events to motorists. Commute times, weather alerts, Amber alerts, and advanced notices of road construction or accidents are common messages.
words.name: Variable-message sign, dynamic message sign, or matrix sign

words.def: A multilateral treaty designed to increase road safety and aid international road traffic by standardizing the signing system for road traffic (road signs, traffic lights and road markings) in use internationally.
words.name: Vienna Convention on Road Signs and Signals

words.def: An international treaty designed to facilitate international road traffic and to increase road safety by establishing standard traffic rules among the contracting parties.
words.name: Vienna Convention on Road Traffic

words.def: A checkpoint along a highway to inspect vehicular weights. Usually, trucks and commercial vehicles are subject to the inspection.
words.name: Weigh station

words.def: See super two
words.name: Wide two lane

words.def: A concurrency between two roads with opposite signed directions, e.g. a westbound highway and an eastbound highway. Often, the physical roadbed is actually headed in a totally different cardinal direction.
words.name: Wrong-way concurrency

words.def: See continuous-flow intersection
words.name: XDL

words.def: An abbreviation for road crossing, primarily used in North America
words.name: Xing or x-ing

words.def: See three-way junction
words.name: Y junction or Y intersection

words.def: A pedestrian crossing marked by alternating dark and light stripes, which typically gives extra rights of way to pedestrians.
words.name: Zebra crossing
